reviewText: We choose how to live our life.  Will it be filled with love and devotion or self-centered motives and lonliness.  Cherry Blossoms allows us to take a deep look into the results of our choices.

reviewText: Since the plot centers around old people, I thought I might be bored but was I surprised. This is a good movie - be patient as the story develops. Very touching. The director did a fine job!

reviewText: if you have ever loved, been lonely, had regrets, or have experienced being too late you will see it gracefully portrayed in this movie. Slow and enchanting as the main character's life draws to a close. You will see yourself and me in a more enlightened way here. Watch it but don't rush through it. You'll miss it if you do.

reviewText: Depending on where you are on life's journey, and/or your deepest sensibilities, this film may be profoundly moving, even gut-wrenching, or NOT.  **Spoilers Follow**Themes that resonate for us tend to be far different when we're young than when we're older, for one thing (duh).  When you have everything ahead of you, issues such as your ability to wield personal power, who am I, really, will I find someone to love and love me, what am I going to do with my life, etc. are of the utmost saliency, urgency.  This movie has to do with the LOSS of things in life that lent it meaning, the water in which you've swum, as ubiquitous as the air you breathe, suddenly drained away.  Shocking.  What now?  Whether you love it or not may depend not only on your age but what you have lost, or if loss looms on your horizon.I found it PROFOUNDLY moving and meaningful, a testament to the fact that life is in our interpretation of it and that to which we choose to attach symbolic meaning.  What is left when everything that seemed to give your life meaning is gone?  Only you, and your ability to experience life as a living work of art of your own creation.  The cremation scene was just one of many I found achingly poignant.  Ticking down to life's conclusion, the protagonist could have just slunk off into old age, gone home and opened a can of beans and turned on the TV, no longer a participant but a spectator in life's pageantry.Instead, he blossoms thru the alchemy of a friendship with a prescient young performance artist (her performances on the toy phone are AMAZING)- and partly as a result of her generosity and courageous example comes to realize that he himself is on stage.  He prepares the performance of a lifetime (literally). I get chills just thinking about it.This film strikes chords that are simultaneously Japanese and reminiscent of Ingmar Bergman, I thought, no less profound. If you liked Bergman'sWild StrawberriesI think you'll like this.  But instead of merely accepting the inevitable and going quietly into that good night, Rudi TRIUMPHS over life's vicissitudes, including that biggest one of them all- death.  He crafts a swan song that is not only the culmination and celebration of a life well-lived, but a testament to love.  The film is utterly original, bizarre, even shocking at times, and for me, GLORIOUS, absolutely mesmerizing, but it's definitely not  for everybody.
summary: MESMERIZING, but not everyone's cup of tea
